and noisy, but the different companies did not get mixed. But our left which consisted of the Az6v and Po- d61sk infantry and the Pavlograd hussars was simultaneously attacked and outflanked by su- perior French forces under Lannes and was thrown into confusion. Bagrati6n had sent Zherk6v to the general commanding that left flank with orders to retreat immediately. 
Zherk6v, not removing his hand from his cap, turned his horse about and galloped off. But no sooner had he left Bagrati6n than his
